with the pressure increase because the force constant between atoms increases with the decrease
of volume. However, the calculated results of the pressure dependency of the lattice vibrations at

. It is well known that the phonon vibration mode is caused by atomic vibrations. In order to
obtain essential information about the atomic displacements giving rise to the vibration modes, the
frequency increases with the pressure increase because the force constant between atoms increases
with the decrease of volume. However, the calculated results of the pressure dependency of the lattice
vibrations at the Γ point of GeSe show that the two lowest frequency Raman-active phonon modes
experience remarkable change at 34 GPa. The pressure dependency of the phonon
frequencies of the Raman-active modes A
and the relevant calculated phonon eigenvectors

vibration modes, the relevant phonon eigenvectors for A
Hydrostatic pressure dependence of the calculated Raman-active B
modes. The corresponding phonon eigenvectors are shown together with the VESTA code.
The displacement pattern associated with the B
phonon mode corresponds to a shearing
motion along the b direction. The A
phonon mode is associated with displacement in the
crystallographic c axis. It can be clearly seen that A
exhibit softening near the phase transition
pressure at 34 GPa. This pressure-induced softening of the low-frequency symmetric mode can be
found in other second-order phase transitions
. From the results, it is evident that a second-
order phase transition takes place, with the transition of crystal symmetry from a simple
) to a high, centered orthorhombic phase (
a displacement type induced by the softening of the low-frequency interlayer phonon mode.
In this work, we investigated extensively the pressure-induced structural, mechanical, and
vibrational properties of GeSe using first principles based on the DFT. The pressure dependencies of
the structural parameters including the lattice parameters, bond lengths, and atomic coordinates
reveal the characteristics of the continuous second-order phase transition of GeSe from
at 34 GPa. The electronic properties undergo significant change under applied pressure. The band
gap of GeSe becomes narrow, and it ultimately closes at 10 GPa. The structural stability of GeSe in
phases is confirmed by the elastic constants and the phonon spectra. The pressure
dependency of the elastic constants and the vibration phonon at the center point reveal the origin of
the second-order phase transition mechanism in GeSe. The group theory analysis shows that the
phase transition is induced by the softening of the low-frequency phonon mode in the interlayer.
J.H.Y. and Q.F. contributed equally to this work. Formal analysis, J.H.Y., Q.F., B.X., and
Y.C.D.; Funding acquisition, J.H.Y. and Q.F.; Investigation, J.H.Y. and Y.C.D.; Methodology, B.X.; Project

ZZ201806, and ZZ201817), and the Science and Technology Bureau of Leshan City (Grant Nos. 18JZD114 and

transition takes place, with the transition of crystal symmetry from a simple orthorhombic phase

). The phase transition is a displacement type
induced by the softening of the low-frequency interlayer phonon mode.
In this work, we investigated extensively the pressure-induced structural, mechanical, and
vibrational properties of GeSe using ﬁrst principles based on the DFT. The pressure dependencies
of the structural parameters including the lattice parameters, bond lengths, and atomic coordinates
reveal the characteristics of the continuous second-order phase transition of GeSe from
at 34 GPa. The electronic properties undergo signiﬁcant change under applied pressure. The band gap
of GeSe becomes narrow, and it ultimately closes at 10 GPa. The structural stability of GeSe in the
phases is conﬁrmed by the elastic constants and the phonon spectra. The pressure
